title: ASX up as BHP shares hit record high on profit jump | Finance Report | ABC NEWS
description: Shares in BHP surged to a new record high after the company's reported profits exceeded expectations, pushing the ASX to its second rise in a row. It marks yet another beat in a favourable reporting season, as finance presenter Alan Kohler explains. title: Man arrested after 'random' stabbing spree on Western Sydney street | ABC NEWS
description: *Warning, this story contains graphic eyewitness accounts of a stabbing attack.* One man has been killed and two other people injured after a man went on a stabbing spree in Merrylands, Western Sydney. title: PM says government will not help ISIS-linked families leave Syria or return home | ABC NEWS
description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says the federal government will not help Australian relatives of ISIS fighters return home from Syria, where they have been held in refugee camps for more than six years.  A group of 11 families left the Al-Roj camp with plans to eventually make the journey to Australia, but were forced to turn back by Syrian authorities. title: Police inspect neighbouring property near Yunta in search for Gus Lamont | ABC NEWS
description: Police in South Australia have called in a cadaver dog to help search for missing boy Gus Lamont in outback Yunta.  The search has expanded to a property neighbouring Oak Park Station where the 4-year-old boy was last seen, also owned by his family. Police inspected an outhouse with freshly laid cement, and a water tank. description: Former NRL winger Matt Utai has undergone surgey in hospital after he was injured in a drive-by shooting in Sydney's west. title: Musician and former NT administrator Ted Egan remembered at state funeral | ABC NEWS
description: An icon of the Northern Territory has been farewelled in Alice Springs today, with 5-hundred people gathering to remember Ted Egan. title: West bank football pitch campaign goes global | ABC NEWS
description: The IDF said the pitch, in the Aida refugee camp in Bethlehem, was constructed without the necessary permits, and its demolition was necessary for security reasons.  The sport's most powerful bodies, FIFA and UEFA, as well as social media influencers such as Ms Rachel, have intervened to pressure Israeli authorities to reconsider its destruction.  The international campaign appears to have forced the Israeli authorities to reconsider, with sources telling the ABC that the IDF has postponed the demolition.  But the Aida Youth Center said it had not received any official notification that the demolition had been called off and it was worried the final whistle could come at any time.  It comes as international outrage grows over Israeli plans, approved by the security cabinet, to tighten the country's grip over the occupied West Bank.  ðŸ“¸ via ABC News by Europe correspondent Bridget Rollason. title: "Not baby terrorists" - should the children of IS fighters be repatriated? | The World | ABC NEWS
description: The Australian Prime Minister has ruled out the repatriation of families linked to Islamic State fighters, who are being held in Syrian refugee camps. 34 women and children attempted to leave al-Roj camp, intending to travel to Australia via Damascus. They were turned around by Syrian authorities, but it's not clear whether they could attempt the journey again. Michael Shoebridge from Strategic Analysis Australia told Yvonne Yong the Australian government has responsibilities to its citizens, and other countries had successfully repatriated families in similar situations. title: Who is Kim Ju Ae, North Korea's likely next leader? | The World | ABC NEWS
description: South Korean intelligence reports have suggested North Korean leader Kim Jong Un is likely to choose his daughter as his successor. Not much is known about Kim Ju Ae, who has been seen in recent public appearances alongside her father, sparking rumours that she's being groomed for the top job. Stephen Nagy from the International Christian University Tokyo spoke to The World's Yvonne Yong about the possible succession plans. title: Liam Alexander Hall revealed as man charged over alleged terrorism act  | ABC NEWS
description: A court has lifted an order concealing the identity of the man accused of throwing a bomb into a crowd at a Perth Invasion Day rally in an alleged act of terrorism.  Police allege Liam Alexander Hall, 32, tossed what they described as a homemade "fragment bomb" filled with ball bearings and screws into the crowd in the heart of Perth's CBD on January 26.  Mr Hall is the first person in Western Australia's history to be charged with a terrorism offence.  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad.
